text: Pours a golden amber with a soft foam head that laces my glass. The aroma is of subtle brett, yeasty, mild brandy booze, grassy and spicy hops, lemon, pineapple, dough bread, and oak notes. Taste is of a pleasant sweet yet spiced brandy, honey, there is a good yeast flavor, bread malts, good acidity, lemon, some blood orange, white grapes, weak peach, soft funk, mild tartness, and a good sour taste. The finish is enjoyable with a soft dryness and the blending of flavors that were listed. The mouthfeel is good and has a medium champagne like carbonation. Overall a very interesting and drinkable beverage.
Hazy Yellow pour with not as much head as expected. Sweet peachy nose but with a horse funk and tart flavor. Quite good sour.

375mL bottle, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Nose brings out brandy barrels upfront, followed by pears, candied sugar and toasted caramel. Flavour is along the same lines, with candied sugar, brandied pears, tart stone fruits and toasted bready notes. Light brett funk in the back. Complex but not hugely enjoyable. Good stuff.

Light golden color with a nice flow of bubbles to sustain a smaller off-white head. Good snappy bubbles. Light pale malt, with some mild floral hops, brett, oak, grape peels, and brandied light fruit. Mildly sweet start, and fairly sweet throughout. Soft bubbly feel. Slightly acetic with some grape peels. The brandy gives a strong presence and adds a light port to chardonnay flavor. Fairly dry in the finish. Wish it was a little less sweet, but I realize thats the brandy at play. Really nice effort.

Randolph Beer: pours gold with small head. Aroma is brandy, bretty funk, yeast, wood and all that fun stuff. Taste is lightly sour and tart. Low sweetness. Nice complexity with some tang to it. Pretty nice.

Smells like sour woody tangerine and peach. Hazy pale yellow with light head. Big front woody tart softens and mellows in to smooth sour fruit light vanilla light bitter wood. So many flavors ever changing.

375mL bottle from Beer Run, 6/30/16. Hazy golden, large foamy white head, good retention. Aroma of brett, citrus, oak, brandy, dandelion. The taste is funk, brett, pineapple, plum, brandy. Medium bodied, lingering tartness, bright, low carbonation. Nice.
Bottle at WTWBA. Light gold pour with a white head. Citrus, some yeast and funk. A little dryness. Extremely well made. Terrific.
Bottle at WTWBA. Light yellow pour. Tart citrus aroma. Citrus peel taste. Pretty good.

Refrigerated 12.7 oz. brown bottle corked and capped pours into a Trappist glass. Slightly hazy golden with medium white head. Aroma is citrus, medium body, highly carbonated, and thick small-bubble lacing. Taste is citrus, oak, spice, a little funky Brett, and hints of honey.  Effervescent, complex, but easy to drink.  Would have guessed Tripel for style.

Oak, barnyard, mildly cheesy funk and persimmon aroma. Hazy amber, medium head, ghostly blue fog that danced in the bottle until poured. Persimmon, with hints of whiskey. Cobweb finish. Light body, spritzy.
375 ml bottle thanks to Lukaduke. Light to medium yellow in color. Yeast and some tartness with grape overtones. Some honey sweetness.
Bottle thanks to AJ. Pours a cloudy golf with medium white head that lasts. The aroma is strong brandy, oak, brett. Medium body, brett, funk, oak, brandy, light dryness, fruity, very nice.

Bottle at home. Pours clear orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is heavy earthy and barnyard Brettanomyces, light citric and lactic acids, Brandy, pears, honey, stone fruit and grainy malt; somewhat grassy late with tangerine notes. Flavor is earthy and barnyard Brettanomyces, tart stone fruit and guava, citrus, oak, grainy malt, honey and a dry finish. Full body and moderate carbonation.
Reddish orange. The aroma isnt really bitter. Very wheat heavy and clean with a light brown sugar. Has a kombucha flavor with wheat, lemon, grape jelly and yeast.

Pours lightly hazy golden yellow with a medium fizzy white head that fades to minimal cap and thin ring. AROMA: wheat, citrus, stone fruit, hay, grassy bitterness, earthy, yeast esters, woody, acidic, herbs, floral hops, lightly tart, mellow funk, leaves, ginger, bubblegum, mellow spice and slight minerals. TASTE: wheat, citrus, stone fruit, hay, grassy bitterness, earthy, woody, acidic, herbs, floral hops, lightly tart, mellow funk, leaves, ginger, bubblegum, mellow spice and lightly metallic. AFTER TASTE: wheat, citrus, stone fruit and herbal hops with a crisp acidic woody finish.

Golden color, large head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is lighter fruit, lightly sour, light funk, vanilla. Medium bodied, moderate to low sourness/funk, vanilla flavor is prevalent. I love brandy aged beers, but this one has barely any notes of it.
Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a fizzy white head. Aroma of oak, lemon, funk and brandy. Flavor was lightly tart and funky with lemon, brandy, honey, yeast and oak.

From the corked caged bottle with a bottling date of Nov 5, 2015. Yellow pour with foamy white head. Aroma of biscuit, Belgian yeast, Brett, coriander, fruit, and brandy barrels. Medium body. The taste has many of the she characters as the mose but more biting in the bitterness. No booze on the nose taste but my head felt it at the end.

375ml bottle - $11.99 at Bullocks Wine & Spirits in Marietta, Georgia.

Date Bottled: Nov. 5, 2015.

Appearance: Pours out a hay-hued body, fairly clear and capped by a slim, white head.

Smell: A tropical whiff of pineapple, a bit of citrus zest and sweet-smelling jellied orchard fruits draped in a layer of faint funk. Honeyish, lightly bready maltiness beneath.

Taste: Sweetish, honeyed bready barley turns to tropical fruits joined with pear and apricot (a bit Juicy Fruit-y) and a little handful of rock candy kernels soaked in brandy. As with the nose, theres a soft, funky, leathery element. Not overtly oaky. Stays a bit sweetish and still rather fruity on the crispish finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-plus carbonation. A little stickiness felt.

Overall: Pretty good. I never felt its ABV, and, while it is a bit on the sweet side, it maintains a free-moving crispness.

Bottle from Hoboken Vine. Pours a clear golden-orange color with a thick, sheeting head. Aroma of oak and funk. Some lemony notes and a bit of brandy come through too. Lots of oak taste. Funky and a bit boozy on the flavor too. Some lemony bitterness on the finish. Clean, funky mouthfeel. Soft carbonation. Pretty tasty.

Slightly hazy yellow orange in color.... Aroma of lemon, citrus, brandy barrel, caramel, funk... Flavor is fairly dry with champagne notes throughout, some light sweetness from brandy that seems a little out of place... Lemon, funk, wood... Decent but they've made better 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
375ml bottle pours a golden color with a bit of head. Lemony citrus sourness. Hops prevalent. Brandy sweetness.

375 ml bottle purchased at Prost, North Hampton, NH. Slightly hazy golden color with a light red hue. Aroma is oak, over ripe fruit, spent squeezed lemons, odd booze note (the Brandy) 
The flavor is again over ripe fruit, mild tannic oak. I dont know the significance of Portuguese Brandy barrel but it is here and gives a big sweetness. The funky yeast or whatever bacteria is here makes an odd combination with this sweet Brandy. The texture is dry from the wood. Interesting overall but for the price, I am not running to buy more bottles.
Bottle (375ml $16): Light golden, 2 finger white head, lots of lacing. Somewhat cloudy. Aroma is funk and fruity. Taste Is fruity and somewhat sweet and sour.

375ml bottles. Shit dogg, some tickers drink some dog poop beer from some mediocre brewery and its sour and they freak out and auto-3.8 that mofo. Clowns. Now let me tell you, the gash makes some of the absolute most refined American sours out there. Theyre one of the best. You can just tell they know what theyre doing and arent just two clowns in a garage with some barrels and some wild bugs of unknown origin. This one just looks great. Mostly clear bright golden, large billowing white head, lively bubbles. The aroma is lemongrass, Bretty funk, oak, and brandy. The flavor is tart, mildly acetic, citric, slight brandy note. Great mouthfeel, exceedingly crisp, clean, and lively feeling. Freaking legit beer, as Ive come to expect from the gash.

Nez très vineux, légèrement aigre, des jolies notes de raisin, fond de champagne. Assez équilibré.
Bouche superbe. Attaque ronde, des levures mais pas éc?urantes, nobles, notes franches de raisin et de champagne. Une petite acidité qui équilibre bien et si donne un peu de pêche et une identité.
Le côté brandy se trouve difficilement mais on peut aller chercher des notes cerises amères.
À tester : on reste sur une bière si nest pas vraiment acide mais qui en titre pourtant les avantages.

Pours hazy gold into a snifter. Bright white head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Lemon, brandy and marshmallow funk aromas. Soft with apricot and summer fruit upfront turning to dried fruit and marshmallow in the dry, lasting finish.

Shared 12.7 oz. bottle poured to my snifter displaying a slightly hazed, golden hue, with a fleeting layer of white head foam, and spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was lightly sweet & spiced, modestly funked, barrel mellowed, and fruit as lemon & pit variety, with a bit of ready alcohol. Light+ bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste was similar notes, tart, citrusy bitterness, moderately boozy, and dry finishing. Balanced and approachably assertive blend of all the notes, but nothing over the top.
(Bouteille): Une poire à peine flambée, une barrique à peine insistante et des bactéries en dormance. Un semi-sipper qui se glisse comme un gant.

Bottled 11/15/15, drunk 3/25/16.A completely clear, golden-brass with light carbonation and an off-white head atop that is well-retained.Ill be honest, when I drank this blind and after when I read it was brandy barrel aged, I definitely had very different opinions. Prior to reading about it, I found it just a bit sweet, simple and possibly too strong. But I think the brandy barrel explains the sweetness and strength. As for the simplicity, its got plenty of fruit, citrus bitterness and vanilla-drenched oak. If you start thinking of it as a brandy-barrel curieux, it begins to sound much more appealing. I dont love Jim Beam barrels and this candy-like sweetness that the brandy adds, with rich tannin and sweet honey-vanilla is hard to argue with. Especially if youre a fan of strong Belgians. Has some light tartness to keep it a little lighter and brighter, even. Carbonation is soft, the texture is candy-sweet and overall its just a shade sweeter than Id prefer. I do see why others love it, though.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2016 Pours a lightly hazy pale golden with a medium white head that keeps replenishing itself and leave nice lacing. Nose is of oak, yellow fruits, white wine and slight spirits. Taste is lightly tart and vinous with a very faint alcohol warmth. A nice, classy barrel-aged sour/wild. Body is medium, carbonation moderate and mouthfeel is juicy x tannic. A little alcohol is felt but what do you expect from a brandy-BA beer? Another really nice barrel aging experiment by Allagash!

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2016 Fruity Bretty dry and with a yeasty brett  kick. The fruitiness from the barrels is quite unique and the strength of this beer. A lot to take in, but thats ok - its too expensive to drink much anyway :). Feel is a bit prickly (3.5) but thats all I didnt love in this beer.

Bottle - 375mL corked and caged. From Nov. 5, 2015 bottling. Translucent gold with a tall, frothy white head. Aroma is woody and fruity with big yeast and flower notes. Taste is peppery spice, yeast, fruit, flowers, hops, lemon, funky notes and earthiness. Body is medium with a strong bubbly carbonation. Dry finish as well. Ends with more yeast, sourdough bread, peppery spice, lemon, woody notes, fruit, flowers and soft hops.

Pours mostly clear golden with a big creamy white head. Aroma is excellent bringing sweet and funky well developed Brett so nice in the nose with a tad of brandy sweetness. Flavor starts with juicy Belgian yeast and then a bit tart from the Brett with a fruity berry brandy note rounding the whole flavor out.

This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a hazy semi-burnt orange / yellow color with a slim quarter fingers worth of white head. Light messy lacing.
The smell took in a some subtle champagne yeast with sweet grassy notes and a sweet to bitter lemon rind and pulp.
The taste, pretty much copied the smell and came across closer to wine than beer in the flavor. Dry champagne-like aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a nice sessionability about it. Carbonation was extremely high like a wine.
Overall, as a Belgian Strong ale, hmmm....yikes, I dont see it, sorry Allagash, not sure what happened here. Do I need to age this longer? More like wine than beer. Disappointed.

Pours golden yellow with intense bubbling carbonation. Head is there but very bubbly then thins out quickly. Smell is sour funk, prune, vinegar, yeast, farmhouse. Taste is smooth, with a funky fruit flavor, notes of honey, bread. Super dry with a hint of brandy. Excellent. Medium body, heavy carb.
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours hazy golden with a nice white head and a honey and citrus aroma. There is a hearty pale malt flavor with a slghtly sour fermented honey sort of flavor.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a small fizzy white head, tiny bit of lace. Nose is vinous and funky with mild brandy and oaky notes and a pronounced Allagash funk. Flavor is well balanced with funk and grapes, light brown sugar, funky oak, tart fruits. Finishes dry and redressing. Allagash always kills.
L cc bottle from Capones. Hazy gold pour with white head. Nice fruity nose with oak and hops. Tasted very fruity, with some lactic tartness, hops, and late oak. Fruity throughout.

375ml bottle in a teku. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of Brett, some light oak and brandy, some pale malts, light fruits, and hints of light spice. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. A solid beer from Allagash.

Bottle. Pours cloudy gold, with a white head. Aroma is lemon, yeast, with some funkiness. Flavor is tart citrus fruit, yeast, alcohol, and brandy on the finish. Goes down rather easy for 9%. Sweeter and less funky than I thought it would be.
Caged and corked bottle. Golden color with a white head. Citrus, tart fruits, wood, some funkiness, and vanilla.

375ml c&c bottle from Xroads. Poured a hazy yellow body under a fizzy white head. Aroma is great, lots of tartness, lemon, light brett, funk, horse blanket, barrel and wet earth with some warming. Flavor is horse bkanket, funk, rotting lemon, cobwebs, hint of brandy, bread crusts. Medium body but big bubbly carbonation comes across as slightly harsh, finishes dry and lingers.

Pours hazy amber with a finger of white head. Aroma of light bretta, citrus, green grapes and apples. Taste opens citrusy tarty followed by a heavy, funky sweet and slightly boozy finish. Medium bodied and smooth with average carbonation.

Not at all inspiring. Would expect more from a $15 12oz bottle. Was hoping for this to be more sour. It was very funky and I could certainly taste the brandy but it just wasnt anything special. Im kind of sceptical to try any of Allagashs other sours because of this.....

Bottle at home late night. Cloudy golden white head. Beautiful nose of tropical ripe fruit and Belgian yeast. Tastes of yeast, stone fruits, star fruit, honey, light brandy, and sauvignon blanc. Very tasty. Medium bodied and only lighty sour. terrific.

Bottle from Meditrina. Sourdough funk perfume floral citrus melon aroma. Tropical fruit melon sweetness with mild funky leather tartness and woody citrus finish. Fairly dry. Nice soft carbo. Decent enough. Some of that leathery funk turns me off these days. I am souring a little on sour beers. I prefer a very clean dry fresh brett beer. Nevertheless, very good.

Bottle from the Bodega
Slightly hazy deep yellow color with a decent sized long lasting bubbly white head. Initially some sulfur on the nose, but that eventually dissipated. Lemony with tart cherries and wisps of honey maltiness. Heavy vinous notes with bits of cereal grainy flavor. Tannic wood is a bit heavy with some sweet stone fruitiness to partially cover. Not my favorite Allagash wild ale, but decent.

Pours a rich golden color with three fingers of white thick foam.

Wet moldy hay, musty basement, dried mango, sercial grapes, orange rind, old wood, cream soda, hot beeswax, bitter dandelion.

Overall nice in complexity and unique flavors without straying to far from what you would expect from Allagash.

Thanks Johnny!

Hazy yellow golden body with a small white collar. Citrus, brett, funk. Subtle, yet beautiful, brandy character. Honey sweetness with assorted citrus. Earthy with mild tartness. Lovely.

375ml bottle pours hazy golden straw with fluffy head. Nose is beautiful with soft toasted oak, honey grain, pineapple, lemon, orange, nice quiet funk and crackly hay. Taste has pricky high carbonation, medium tartness, very dry, toasted grain and hay with funky pineapple, peach, orange, stonefruit, some white grape and prominent oak. Finishes dry, tart, dusty hay, dough, citrus, tropical fruit, oak. Great.
Draft. Wow a funky beer. Dill savory and a nice bit of barnyard. Its pretty nice thought.

Pouring at Sourd in September 2014, at Captain Lawrence. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Soft musky yeast and sweetness on the nose. Sweet wood, booze, caramel and brandy. Medium bodied, sweet and faintly herbal. Grapes and soft acid, tartness. Warm wood and brandy. Caramel, toast, sweet acid.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Hazy orange pour with a minimal head. Strong medium citrus flavors. Orange peels and pith. Hints of heavier flavors. Enough hops to balance out the citrus. Feels like a fuzzy juicy fruity citrus sour that gets a bit lost on the woods.

Nice fruity aroma with some candy, bread, and Belgian hops. Taste was fruity, lightly bitter, and somewhat sour. More of a sour ale than anything else. Typically not my cup of tea, but this was a fine beer and obviously really well made.

Draft at ChurchKey. Hazy golden pour, solid frothy white head. Nose and flavor bring unripe apricot, hints of mango, sauvignon blanc, tannic funk, light but present tartness, and boozy sweetness. Lovely combination of stone fruit, Cointreau-like liqueur sweetness, and barrel forward funk, all balancing nicely. Reminiscent of a softer, less aggressive Anchorage Tide and its Takers. Nancy was definitely the showstopper of these two new excellent Allagash sours, but I think Evora is the better beer. Superb as always from this brewery.

4oz pour at Churchkeys Night of the Living Ales 2014. Pours a hazy gold with some creamy, white head. Nose has some booze, mild woodiness, a little buttery, floral, a little lemon-lime soda, some agave. Flavor has agave syrup, wood pulp, hints of caramel, woody, vegetal, straw, mild Vitamin C. Pulpy finish.
Draft at Churchkey. Clear golden color. Aroms of dusty overripe fruit. Taste is softly sour stone fruit, vanilla. Goes down smooth as silk.
On draft at ChurchKey in D.C. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Apple cider nose. Flavors of citrus, oak and a bit of vanilla and mint. Lovely melange of flavors.
On tap at the brickstore. Light honey colored pour. Bit of honey on the finish. Medium tartness and good balance with a mild triple sort of action with the base beer.
Gold pour. Aroma of tart and oak. Tastes smooth, caramel, spicy, grapes, bretta funk. The brandy barrel takes over. Perfect amount of sour. minerals. Smooth creamy tart palate.
Draft. Golden pour with white head. Tart fruit and dry yeast aromas. Sweetness, belgian fruit, oak, Brandy and barrel tones.

Another excellent Allagash. Comes together super well with great head and lacing. A little bitterness and tartness on finish. Well balanced as usual. Great head and lacing. Light bretta and some florals with a little barrel. Tap at Snallygaster.

Draft, Snallygaster. Small off-white head with hazy light amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, Brett, some cherry, light orange. Taste is moderately sweet, Brett/cherry, light lemon, orange. Medium body, some stickiness.

6 oz draft pour at Snallygaster 2014 shared by someone. Golden yellow with off-white head. Aromas of light funk, floral notes, spice. Tastes of citrus, light funk, floral notes, spice. Medium-light body with a dry finish.

draft at Sourd in September @ Captain Lawrence, goldenish pur. pretty complex notes of oak, lemony citrus, brandy, light bandaid notes. vast flavors melded well together. looking forward to having more
Tap at Snallygaster 2014. One of the best of the day. Very complex, full bodied and funky. Loved this one.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2016 Bottle. Pours gold white head. Nose/taste of brandy, white grape, desert wine, oak and sour lemon fruits. Wild yeasts. Medium body.
